title.narrative: Strengthening Civil Courage – External Stress Factors / International Lobby and Advocacy

description.narrative: In the Strengthening Civil Courage programme, the pillar of work called External Stress Factors (ESF) is aimed primarily at taking away stress factors that are external to the conflict. The conflicts in which the alliance is seeking to implement its programme have a myriad of external stress factors. For the international lobby and advocacy component of the work on external stress factors, the alliance seeks to address the factors caused by two types of actors: states and companies. Impact through environmental factors is also part of the programme.

The activity is part of a larger programme implemented by the Strengthening Civil Courage Alliance, consisting of ABAAD – Resource Center for Gender Equality, Amnesty International The Netherlands, DefendDefenders, PAX and their partner networks.

The main objective for this programme is that states, companies and other actors contribute to effective international standards which protect people against harm caused through the effects of weapons, business activities in conflict-affected areas or environmental impacts of conflict. More specifically, the programme aims for states to contribute to effective international standards regulating the use of and trade in (controversial) weapons; and, for companies to adhere to effective international standards that prevent and mitigate human rights impacts of businesses in conflict. Lastly, the programme aims to address and mitigate environmental impact of warfare.

The programme targets states, the Dutch government, the UN and multilateral bodies, arms companies, affected communities, financial institutions, multinational companies, and consumers in Western countries.

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 19318 3501 DH Utrecht The Netherlands

sector.narrative: Civilian peacebuilding, conflict prevention and resolution

title.narrative: Outcome 2.1 Financial institutions have systems and mechanisms in place to prevent, mitigate and remediate adverse human rights impacts of their investments in companies producing weapons or involved in human rights violations.

# of financial institutions that have systems and mechanisms in place to prevent, mitigate and remediate adverse human rights impacts of their investments in companies producing weapons or involved in human rights violations (SCS 2)

comment.narrative: 0 EU financial institutions have improved systems and mechanisms
Up to 15 EU financial institutions have improved systems and mechanisms

title.narrative: Output 1.1.1 - Research publications and advocacy initiatives on the direct, indirect and reverberating harm resulting from EWIPA feeds into international discussions on the issue.
# of research publications and advocacy initiatives on the direct, indirect and reverberating harm resulting from EWIPA feeds into international discussions on the issue. (SCS 4)

comment.narrative: 10 research publications and accompagnying advocacy initiatives have been produced by PAX over the past years
4 research publications and advocacy initiatives on the direct, indirect and reverberating harm resulting from EWIPA fed into international discussions on the issue.

title.narrative: Outcome 1.1 States contribute to international standards aiming to prevent civilian suffering from EWIPA and the use of drones and placing robust limits on arms exports, including drones, to high risk countries.
# of States and international bodies explaining their arms export policy in the context of the Arms Trade Treaty (ATT) (SCS 2)

comment.narrative: Most states are highly reluctant to explain or discuss concrete export policies within the ATT.
Discussing specific arms exports in plenary ATT contexts has become an accepted norm.

title.narrative: A new international agreement on explosive weapons in populated areas (SCS 2)

comment.narrative: States are negotiating a potential political declaration to prevent the civilian suffering from the use of explosive weapons in populated areas.

title.narrative: Outcome 2.3 Multinational companies active in conflict-affected areas adopt heightened due diligence mechanisms in conflict-affected areas
# companies that endorse heightened due diligence mechanisms (SCS 2)

comment.narrative: There has not been a VPI plenary meeting decision on heightened due diligence.
1 Voluntary Principles Initiative Plenary meeting decision on heightened due diligence for companies with operations in conflict areas.
